title-group.article-title: Capta versus Data: Method and Evidence in Communicology

ref.mixed-citation: Alexander, H.G. (1988). The language and logic of philosophy. Lanham, NY: University Press of America.
Bühler, K. (1934/1990). Theory of language: The representational function of language. Foundations of Semiotics, Vol. 25. Trans. D.F. Goodwin. Philadel¬ phia: John Benjamins Publishing Co.
Corner, J. and Hawthorn, J. (Eds.) (1989). Communication studies: An introductory reader. 3rd ed. London and New York: Edward Arnold Publishers.
Hawking, S. (1988). A brief history of time: From the big bang to black holes. New York: Bantam Books.
Kaelin, E.F. and Schrag, C.O. (Eds.). (1989). American phenomenology: Origins and developments. Analecta Husserliana, Vol. 26. Boston: Kluwer Academic Publishers.

King, B. (1992). Semiotic determinism and the photographic sign: Towards a theory of textual determinism after post-structuralism. Paper presented at the meeting of the Commission on Semiotics and Communication, Speech Com¬ munication Association, Chicago, Illinois, USA.
Kristeva, J. (1989). Language, the unknown: An initiation into linguistics. Trans. A.M. Menke. New York: Columbia University Press.
Lanigan, R.L (1977). Speech act phenomenology. The Hague and Boston: Martinus Nijhoff Publishers.
Lanigan, R.L. (1988). Phenomenology of communication: Merleau-Ponty's thematics in communicology and semiology. Pittsburgh: Duquesne University Press.

Lanigan, R.L. (1991). Speaking and semiology: Maurice Merleau-Ponty's phenomenological theory of existential communication. 2nd ed. Approaches to Semiotics, Vol. 22. Berlin and New York: Mouton de Gruyter.
Lanigan, R.L. (1992). The human science of communicology: A phenomenology of discourse in Foucault and Merleau-Ponty. Pittsburgh: Duquesne University Press.

Lanigan, R.L. (1994, in press). A good rhetoric is possible: Ricoeur's philosophy of language as a phenomenology of discourse in the human sciences. In L.E. Hahn (Ed.), Paul Ricoeur. The Library of Living Philosophers. Peru, IL: The Open Court Publishing Co.
Luria, A.R. (1976). Cognitive development: Its cultural and social foundations. Trans. M. Lopez-Morillas and L. Solotaroff. Cambridge: Harvard University Perss.
Merleau-Ponty, M. (1964). Signs. Trans. R.C. McCleary. Evanston: Northwestern University Perss.
Ricoeur, P. (1977). Phenomenology and the social sciences. The Annals of Phenomenological Sociology 2: 145-159.
Sobchack, V. (1992). The address of the eye: A phenomenology of film experience. Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press.

Spiegelberg, H. (1982). The phenomenological movement: A historical introduc¬ tion. Phaenomenologica, Vol. 5/6. 3rd revised and enlarged ed. with the collaboration of K. Schuhmann. The Hague and Boston: Martinus Nijhoff Publishers.
Wilden, A. (1987). The Rules are no game: The strategy of communication. London and New York: Routledge & Kegan Paul.
